subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Dutch QuikScript = Snelsgrift
msgSnippet: Sounds great, Jerry, looking forward to seeing your sample. jon ... From: Jerry [mailto:nieuwsgroep222@xs4all.nl] Sent: Tuesday, May 18, 2004 6:19 PM To:
messageBody:
Message
Sounds great, Jerry, looking forward to seeing your sample.
 
jon
-----Original Message-----
From: Jerry [mailto:nieuwsgroep222@...]
Sent: Tuesday, May 18, 2004 6:19 PM
To: read_alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Dutch QuikScript = Snelsgrift

Hi,

In March, I was searching for a good shorthand-like system, and I found
QuickScript.

The only problem with QuickScript is that it is not usable at all with
foreign languages. I'm Dutch myself, and I wanted to use QuickScript for my
daily writings. So I decided to adapt QuickScript to make it usable for the
Dutch language.

It's quite a big advantage that QuickScript has a large alphabet. Many
typical English sounds are not present at all in Dutch, and the other way
round. For example, QuickScript features two different letters for the 'th'
sounds, both of which are not present in Dutch. I decided to replace these
two sounds, number 7 and 8 in the alphabet list, with the very similar Dutch
diphthongs 'eu' and 'ui'. In that way English QuickScript would still be
readable by remembering that Dutch eu/ui QuickScript meant 'th' in English.

In this way I adapted the entire QuickScript alphabet to the Dutch language.
I've been using my Dutch adaptation for 64 for days now, and successfully.

I encountered only one problem. The first and the last vocals in the Dutch
word 'geschreven' are not pronounced equally, but the untrained ear doesn't
hear the difference. Because of that, I used the same QuickScript letter no.
36 to represent both.

Geschreven is written like 'gusgreevun' in Dutch QuickScript
transliteration, which looks very childish to the Dutch. Now I understand
why a spelling reform can never be successful without a new alphabet :-)

My Dutch QuickScript adaptation is as follows (first column letter number,
second the English pronunciation, third the new Dutch pronunciation).

1      P-ea            P-ak
2      B-ay            B-aai
3      T-ea            TH-ee
4      D-ay            D-ag
5      K-ey            K-oe
6      G-ay            G-oed, ka-CH-el
7      TH-aw            EU-ropa
8      TH-ey            UI-er
9      F-ee            F-oppen
10      V-ie            V-is
11      S-ee            S-chool
12      Z-oo            Z-ien
13      SH-e            CH-irurg
14      vi-SI-on       J-am
15      CH-eer       TSJ-ilpen
16      J-ay             As English
17      Y-e             J-acht
18      W-ay             W-eg
19      H-e             H-ij
20      Wh-y             -
21      -iNG            e-NG-els
22      M-ay            M-ogen
23      N-o            N-ee
24      L-ow            L-aag
25      R-oe            R-ichel
26      I-t            I-k
27      EA-t            IE-ts
28      E-t            E-kster
29      EIGH-t      EE-rst
30      A-t            IJ-s/r-EI-zen
31      I            AI-aiai
32      A-h            A-msterdam
33      AWE            k-AA-s
34      O-x            O-mroep
35      OY            h-OI
36      U-tter      g-E-schrev-E-n
37      OU-t            g-OU-d/g-AU-w
38      OWE            OO-k
39      f-OO-t      v-OE-t
40      OO-ze            m-UU-r

The only contraction I've made yet is that of the three Dutch articles 'de',
'het' and 'een' which are replaced by the Dutch QuickScript letters no. 4
(d), 19 (h) and 36 (u).

In the near future I will also post the Dutch QuickScript alphabet as a
image.

The Dutch equivalent of 'quikscript' is 'snelsgrift'.

Regards,
Jerry

jon
